data.title: Count the words
data.statement:
You receive a encoded string, fortunately, you know how it has been coded, you just have to shift the i-th letter in the original message by i places in the alphabet, eventually looping back from Z to A.
So {{Hello World!}} become {{Igopt Cvzun!}} because {{H}}+1 = {{I}}, {{e}}+2 = {{g}}, {{l}}+3 = {{o}}, {{l}}+4 = {{p}}, {{o}}+5 = {{t}}, {{space}} is unchanged, not being a letter, {{W}}+6 = {{C}}, for you go back to {{A}} after {{Z}}.
The goal is to output the most frequent word in the decoded message. The counting must not be case sensitive, {{Hello}} is the same as {{HELLO}}.
There will never be a doubt about which word to send as the most frequent will always be a unique most frequent.
For example, in the first case, after decoding, you obtain {{If you were to ever look closely at that string uncoded, you would probably be able to tell that the word you read the most in it is 'you'. In fact, you have read 'you' six times already.}} so you must output {{you}} as it is the most frequent word
A word is considered ended when encountering a non-letter character, such as a white space ({{ }}), an apostrophe ({{'}}) or a point ({{.}}).

testCases.title: Short Sentence
testCases.testIn: Jh bsz clzn dz qisg bfgd wgkpcky bv wlfz zbasys hbreuww, sjq tmtle rusggith lp mozt jf lxfg peys tig zswj fwd bpmq hwu dgln dj fr hs 'zqx'. Ms lhkc, izg uoku iwtx 'tkr' qhx ukpix gsznkok.

data.constraints:
50 ≤ length of [[code]] ≤ 2050
10 ≤ number of words in [[code]] ≤ 300
1 ≤ length of any word ≤ 15
data.stubGenerator:
read code:string(2050)

write The one and only word more frequent than the others.
data.inputDescription: One line, a string [[code]], that you must decypher.
data.outputDescription: The most frequently used word in the decoded message, in lower case

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

You receive a encoded string, fortunately, you know how it has been coded, you just have to shift the i-th letter in the original message by i places in the alphabet, eventually looping back from Z to A.
So Hello World! become Igopt Cvzun! because H+1 = I, e+2 = g, l+3 = o, l+4 = p, o+5 = t, space is unchanged, not being a letter, W+6 = C, for you go back to A after Z.
The goal is to output the most frequent word in the decoded message. The counting must not be case sensitive, Hello is the same as HELLO.
There will never be a doubt about which word to send as the most frequent will always be a unique most frequent.
For example, in the first case, after decoding, you obtain If you were to ever look closely at that string uncoded, you would probably be able to tell that the word you read the most in it is 'you'. In fact, you have read 'you' six times already. so you must output you as it is the most frequent word
A word is considered ended when encountering a non-letter character, such as a white space ( ), an apostrophe (') or a point (.).
Input
One line, a string code, that you must decypher.
Output
The most frequently used word in the decoded message, in lower case
Constraints
50 ≤ length of code ≤ 2050
10 ≤ number of words in code ≤ 300
1 ≤ length of any word ≤ 15
Example
Input
Jh bsz clzn dz qisg bfgd wgkpcky bv wlfz zbasys hbreuww, sjq tmtle rusggith lp mozt jf lxfg peys tig zswj fwd bpmq hwu dgln dj fr hs 'zqx'. Ms lhkc, izg uoku iwtx 'tkr' qhx ukpix gsznkok.
Output
you
